qas.question: Which principles did Leibniz's arguments trade heavily upon?

answers.text: the principle of sufficient reason and the identity of indiscernibles

qas.question: Leibnitz held that there is a reason that is sufficient to explain what and why it is the way it is and not otherwise for every what?
What states that if there is no way of telling two entities apart, then they are one and the same thing?

plausible_answers.text: the principle of sufficient reason and the identity of indiscernibles

qas.question: What two principles did Leibniz argue against?
What states that two things are not necessarily the same just because no difference can be identified?

context: Arguing against <a0_0>the <b4_0>absolutist<b4_0/> position<a0_0/>, Leibniz offers a number of thought experiments with the purpose of showing that there is contradiction in assuming the existence of facts such as absolute location and velocity. These arguments trade heavily on two principles central to his philosophy: <a1_0><b5_0>the principle of sufficient reason and the identity of indiscernibles<b5_0/><a1_0/>. The principle of sufficient reason holds that for every <a2_0>fact<a2_0/>, there is a reason that is sufficient to explain what and why it is the way it is and not otherwise. <b6_0>The <a3_0>identity of indiscernibles<a3_0/> states<b6_0/> that if there is no way of telling two entities apart, then they are one and the same thing.
